items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force due to high tides that may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast today, Monday 26/12/2022, between 7:00pm and 10:00pm. The particular area at risk is around Kilnsea village. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 10pm on 26/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to high tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast today, Monday 26/12/2022, between 6:30 PM and 8:30 PM. Areas most at risk include low lying coastal frontages, in particular around Kilnsea Caravan Park and Southfield Farm coastal side. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 26/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 05:00 on 27/12/22 and 4.70 mAOD at 17:30 on 27/12/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are steady. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 140 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are rising again on the Upper River Wey following earlier rainfall. 
Therefore, flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected today 26/12/22. 
The forecast is for a largely drier day with some scattered showers possible. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:30 tomorrow morning, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels remain high at the Bradford on Avon river gauge because of the rainfall over the past few days but are beginning to fall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Further rainfall is expected in the evening of Tuesday 27/12/ 2022 and on Wednesday 28/12/2022. River levels are expected to rise again because of this rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Tuesday, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Chertsey Bourne following earlier heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today 26/12/22. 
The forecast is for a largely drier day with some scattered showers possible. 
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Light rainfall is forecast for tomorrow, 27/12/2022, though no flooding impacts are expected.   
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  
Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
We expect flood levels to remain high until after the high tide tonight, 26/12/2022.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Monday, 26/11/22. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Today is forecast to be drier with isolated showers possible. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Please refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Tuesday, 27/11/22, or as the situation changes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message:

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely throughout this evening, Monday 26 December and overnight into Tuesday 27 December. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Tuesday 27 December.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen following recent rainfall. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Some further rain is forecast on Wednesday 28 December however we do not currently expect any further impacts on river levels. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
No significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by midday on 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
The Thames Barrier is being operated today at 13:30. 
The next high tide is forecast to reach between 4.96 metres and 5.05 metres. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and tides and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels remain high at the Great Somerford river gauge because of the rainfall over the past few days but are beginning to fall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge. Further rainfall is expected in the evening of Tuesday 27/12/2022 and on Wednesday 28/12/2022. River levels are expected to rise again because of this rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 14:00 on Tuesday, 27/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.26 m and is stable. 

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.26 m and is stable. 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

Unsettled weather is forecast for the next 48hrs.

The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable as a result.

Flooding is possible in this area.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Loddon following earlier heavy rainfall. 
Therefore, flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today, 26/12/22. 
The forecast is for a largely drier day with some scattered showers possible. 
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.48 m and is rising by falling 10 mm per hour.

Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.

The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.6 m and is rising by approximately 10 mm per hour. 

There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.

Unsettled weather is forecast for the next 48 hours.

The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to remain stable as a result.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but steady on the Lower Cherwell as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today, 26/12/2022, especially in the areas around Thrupp. 
Today is forecast to be mainly dry, with further rainfall showers expected tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 26/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels remain high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of recent rainfall, consequently flooding of roads and farmland may continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge. We expect river levels to remain elevated for the next few days and potentially impacted by additional rainfall forecast for 27/12/22. This message will be updated by 12:00pm on 27/12/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. This alert has been issued due to elevated river levels around Sandford. This message will not be updated, but river levels may rise further and come out of banks. Please take care when walking along the Thames Path and check River Levels online for current levels at Kings Lock, Godstow Lock, Osney Lock, Iffly Lock, Minns Estate and Cold Harbour.
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/22, or as the situation changes.
